item.title: Ticket #979 (way of knowing if in "the loop"?) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code

item.title: Ticket #979 (way of knowing if in "the loop"?) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code

item.title: Ticket #979 (way of knowing if in "the loop"?) created
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description:
As far as I know there is no good (as in reliable and clear) way of knowing if a function is being executed within "the loop" or not.

I have in the past created, or attempted to implement, functions that could be overloaded -- ie., if being executed within the loop the function would pertain only to that post, but if outside of the loop, then apply to all posts. However, due to bug #977, if the function were to occur outside the loop, but also AFTER the loop, I couldn't use the admittedly hackish check of: global $id, if ($id == ) : we're outside the loop

item.title: Ticket #978 (slashes not stripped) updated
item.dc:creator: hpnadig

item.title: Ticket #978 (slashes not stripped) created
item.dc:creator: hpnadig
item.description: When a theme's name has a " ' ", slashes get added to the name (description) on the theme editor.

item.title: Ticket #977 (the loop should clean up after itself) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code

item.title: Ticket #977 (the loop should clean up after itself) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code

item.title: Ticket #977 (the loop should clean up after itself) created
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description:
The loop, by calling the_post(), sets up various global variables with values relevant to each post as it iterates through posts. However, when the loop is done, the global variables are left with the values set from the last iteration.

Other than being cleaner, this has relevance to the followup bug report I'll submit, a feature request which should soon be listed as having a dependent relationship to this bug.

item.dc:creator: ryan

item.title: Ticket #973 (Wrong variable on line 509 of /wp-includes/links.php) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: $orderby provides the sort order specified for the link category in the database. If you want to change an order for a link category, change it in the database. The $order argument of get_links_list() applies only to the order of the link categories, not the links within each category.

item.title: Ticket #914 (wrong search string escaping/slashes) updated
item.dc:creator: nbachiyski
item.description:
In classes.php $qs? is added slashes again, despite the fact that is has passed through add_magic_quotes function before.

For database use the search string needs slashes, but when writing it to the templates is does not. I have added striptags calls in the template pages.

item.title: Ticket #974 (Unescaped ampersands in Link Manager) updated
item.dc:creator: 2fargon

item.title: Ticket #974 (Unescaped ampersands in Link Manager) created
item.dc:creator: 2fargon
item.description:
The bug is described in detail at ​http://priyadi.net/archives/2005/02/25/wordpress-15-bugs/.

The excerpt: I found an irritating bug in Wordpress 1.5: ampersands in blogroll URLs donât get properly escaped. Thus, blogrolls that contains URL with ampersand in it donât validate.

Quick fix: modify wp-includes/links.php around line 206 like this (add the line with + in front of it)

item.title: Ticket #973 (Wrong variable on line 509 of /wp-includes/links.php) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger

item.title: Ticket #973 (Wrong variable on line 509 of /wp-includes/links.php) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: The variable $orderby should be changed to $order on line 509 of /wp-includes/links.php. The incorrect variable means that any call to get_links_list() with the first argument filled will not have any effect. So get_links_list('name') was still ordering by rand() for me.

item.title: Ticket #969 (<!--more--> ignored when only 1 post matches) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code

item.title: Ticket #969 (<!--more--> ignored when only 1 post matches) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code

item.title: Ticket #969 (<!--more--> ignored when only 1 post matches) created
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description:
Saw this on the support forum: ​http://wordpress.org/support/topic.php?id=23850

Basically, if the blog is set to only display one post on the index.php page, or if a category/date-based archive page is accessed and only one post matches, then the < !--more-- > is ignored and the whole post is displayed. As others in the aforementioned thread indicate, and for which I agree, the < !--more-- > should always be recognized except for the permalink page for the post, which is the one instance where the entire post should be displayed.

item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Preserve entity encoding in plugin editor. ​http://mosquito.wordpress.org/view.php?id=957 Props: coffee2code

item.title: Ticket #957 (Plugin Editor messes up entities) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description:
Patch changed

wp-admin/plugin-editor.php used wp_specialchars() to filter the file contents, whereas wp-admin/theme-editor.php used htmlspecialchars(). In this instance, we DO want the double-encoding of HTML entities (which wp_specialchars() was built to prevent), so I suggest we use htmlspecialchars() here. Patch attached, bug957_plugin-editor.diff; tested and seems to work.

item.title: Ticket #957 (Plugin Editor messes up entities) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description:
Patch changed

Original attached file was an example and not a patch.

item.title: Ticket #967 (publish_post is not triggered via xml-rpc or email posting) updated
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description: Actually, what is needed is specific XMLRPC hooks. We can not copy hooks made with a particular purpose in mind and expect they'll work the same elsewhere. For example with this patch, do_trackbacks() wouldn't trackback anything when making a new post, because the field to_ping wouldn't be populated yet.

item.title: Ticket #967 (publish_post is not triggered via xml-rpc or email posting) updated
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description: Forgot to mention, didn't touch email posting for now, as it has the action 'publish_phone' hooked in. Maybe plugins that add an action for publish_post should silently have a publish_phone action added as well? Would produce the most expected behaviour IMHO. Either that or copy the same code block again? If that was the case it would be reproduced 6 times (and thus a possible candidate for being its own reusable function maybe?)

item.title: Ticket #967 (publish_post is not triggered via xml-rpc or email posting) updated
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description: Uploaded a patch which adds the required hooks. Actually, just lifted the same code from post.php, but haven't had a chance to test it out yet. Also adds hooks for trackbacks, enclosures, and pingbacks if specified. Quick and dirty, and in need of review before committing, but might do the trick. J.

item.title: Ticket #966 (Previous/next page breaks when asked for displaying n days worth of posts) updated
item.dc:creator: excalin

item.title: Ticket #966 (Previous/next page breaks when asked for displaying n days worth of posts) created
item.dc:creator: excalin
item.description:
My blog showed incorrect "next page" links generated by posts_nav_link, which led to 404 errors. After a lot of research (I'm not familiar with wordpress code) I've discovered that the calculation for the correct number of pages is not done when n days of posts per page is selected (in posts_nav_link, $max_page is set to 999999).

It would be great if this restriction could be lifted, or at least some comments were put there in order to warn users.

As a side note, Kubrick uses 2 or 4 calls to posts_nav_link per page ; this seems a bit like an overkill. It would be great if a more general function could be supplied, which would better serve Kubrick.

item.title: Ticket #965 (get_post_meta inefficient if used in loop and meta key not in cache) updated
item.dc:creator: gbhugo

item.title: Ticket #965 (get_post_meta inefficient if used in loop and meta key not in cache) created
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description:
When the meta key is not in the cache for the data from the loop, access to get_post_meta(...) with an ID of a posting in the loop will still produce a SELECT, because the value can't be found in the cache and so it assumes the cache is stale and needs updating. But for posts in the loop, the cache is already fully populated.

An idea (as outlined in the patch in the additional not) could be to give get_post_meta another parameter with default false that if set to true will suppress the SELECT in assuming that the cache can't be stale because we access something from the loop. I called this parameter "fast" processing - it's not full processing, because if used on posts not in the loop will miss data.

The problem is, if you use many metadata in your posts for example because you stored old permalinks in meta tags from older software, your index.php will make unneccessary SELECTS for newer posts where those meta data isn't filled. This unneccessary SELECT happens for every meta item for every post on the page ...

item.title: Ticket #964 (Default theme has links to WP installations ('siteurl') instead of ...) updated
item.dc:creator: jamesvl

item.title: Ticket #964 (Default theme has links to WP installations ('siteurl') instead of ...) created
item.dc:creator: jamesvl
item.description:
When browsing a category page using the default WP 1.5 template, the sidebar provides a description of the category being browsed and a link to the blog.

The link provided links to the WP installation directory instead of to the blog home. For all users where the two are different this would be considered incorrect behavior, even though is *probably* doesn't break their site.

item.title: Ticket #891 (wrong date used in wp-rss2.php) updated
item.dc:creator: jesse
item.description:
Maybe we should use get_post_time($timestr, true) instead of get_the_time($timestr)?

--- wp-rss2.php (revision 85) +++ wp-rss2.php (working copy) @@ -33,7 +33,7 @@

<title><?php the_title_rss() ?></title> <link><?php permalink_single_rss() ?></link> <comments><?php comments_link(); ?></comments>

  • <pubDate><?php echo mysql2date('D, d M Y H:i:s +0000', get_the_time('Y-m-d H:i:s'), false); ?></pubDate>

+ <pubDate><?php echo mysql2date('D, d M Y H:i:s +0000', get_post_time('Y-m-d H:i:s', true), false); ?></pubDate>

<dc:creator><?php the_author() ?></dc:creator> <?php the_category_rss() ?>

item.title: Ticket #962 (Pages with the same title but different parents don't work.) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger

item.title: Ticket #962 (Pages with the same title but different parents don't work.) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
Pages with the same title but different parents don't render properly. For example, ​http://www.thewordnerd.info/about and ​http://www.thewordnerd.info/music/about display the same information for both pages on both pages.

I've tried changing the slug of /music/about to music-about, but that changes the URL and results in a 404.

It seems that combining the page title with its parent would result in a unique match for pages, and that would result in only one being returned per query, but I'm still coming to terms with the code, so am not sure how this could be made to work.

I noticed this problem when installing 1.5, and I've been following CVS in hopes that it would vanish, but it still persists.
